Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR)Spectrometer to Enable Material Science Research
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of California Berkeley is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer equipped with 1.3 mm and 3.2 mm solid-state probes, a diffusion probe, and micro-imaging capabilities to support Jeffrey Reimer, Hasan Celik, and other colleagues. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, batteries, as well as permitting study of biologically relevant species. In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution and nearby universities.<br/><br/>The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts spectroscopic development of analytical methods to investigate porous and soft materials. The instrumentation is also used for studying supramolecular materials commonly known as MOFs (metal-organic frameworks) capable of absorbing and exchanging gases. In addition, it provides information for developing solid polymer electrolytes for lithium batteries. The NMR spectrometer is also used to sequence dependent materials by optimizing the chemistry of MOF synthesis to establish the relationship between chemical functionality and diffusion rates, and kinetics of uptake and release of substrates.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preparation of novel functional materials with useful properties requires a rational and iterative process of design, synthesis, and characterization. Recent methodological efforts in synthetic chemistry have afforded a wide range of new solid materials with unprecedented electronic, magnetic, optical and storage capabilities. These materials will play a critical role in tackling major societal challenges such as climate change, shrinking natural resources, and materials supply. However, the characterization of solid-state materials typically requires a combination of techniques to obtain a comprehensive analysis of structural, electronic, and magnetic properties. One of the most important techniques used to analyze such materials is nuclear magnetic resonance, which as a powerful spectroscopic and imaging method can provide unprecedented insight that is not replicable by other methods. NMR’s role is central to iterative design and discovery for materials that are inherently challenging to determine structure and physical properties of porous, amorphous or microcrystalline constructs. The grant award provided a large group of materials scientists at UC Berkeley and nearby Bay Area institutions with a state-of-the-art NMR spectrometer that enabled new material characterization capacities with much improved detection and experimental capabilities.

Throughout the award, we utilized these new NMR tools enabled by the new spectrometer to support multi-modal materials discovery via solid-state and diffusion NMR, and micro-imaging applications that allowed us to probe chemical information at molecular and micro level, as well as transport and dynamic properties. This multi-pronged approach afforded the innovation of new materials with groundbreaking properties or provided a better understanding of mechanisms from emerging trends in materials design to iteratively refine their performance and properties. Some of the key outcomes of the project include:

  • the discovery of a new covalent organic framework material for direct air capture of carbon dioxide,
  • the discovery of a new class of circularly recyclable plastics that can operate at higher temperatures,
  • the discovery of an organic nanocomposite as a mixed conductor,
  • detailed understanding of transport properties in emerging battery electrolyte materials.

There are numerous ongoing materials discovery and analysis projects at UC Berkeley that will continue to benefit beyond the grant period from the research and instrumentation infrastructure created by this award. In total, the research support provided by the new NMR spectrometer led to 6 scientific papers, some of which in high-impact international journals. Accompanying this effort, the project allowed the training and academic development of 55 students and researchers, from undergraduate to graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and scholars in general. Finally, this project helped develop various institutional resources, e.g., in the form of new curricula for course work and educational materials.
